body: cc  @dynamix @mikehinchey

Hi @xy2953396112 , before making a PR, you can compile and test in local first.
To add a function, you also need to define this method in `RexImpTable`.
Hi, the last two commits, just merge from master and modify the commit message.
LGTM
Also please fix the build fail.
Thanks for reviewing! @hsyuan
Maybe it's not a bug, I will close it.
Thanks for the review @hsyuan
Thanks for approve !
@LaiZhou could you please rebase and squash the commits into a single one with the [appropriate commit message](https://calcite.apache.org/develop/#contributing)?

Checks is failed because:
`
[00:20:59] [ERROR] Tests run: 29, Failures: 0, Errors: 28, Skipped: 1, Time elapsed: 3.999 s <<< FAILURE! - in org.apache.calcite.test.PigRelExTest
`
But the testcase org.apache.calcite.test.PigRelExTest was successfully executed locally.  I am not sure why it will fail.  I also seen the same failed message in https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/1420, @hsyuan , can you help to take a look at the failed message.
@rubenada ,rebase done.
@hsyuan Can you help to review this PR,  thanks.
I noticed this for the first time after https://github.com/apache/calcite/commit/e5ae1796e8016b0a5e943f458bf31a7e7e8aa75a
Thanks @ihuzenko ,the AppVeyor is still failing, does this patch solve the problem ?
Hello @danny0405 , the fix enables one of Pig plan optimizations. Fails on AppVeyor is another env specific issue.
Closing as this issue was fixed by https://github.com/apache/calcite/commit/01477c42ded991aaa7b14cf72a6e4ea1a20edf5e.
@shenh062326 I don't think the failed test is related with your change.
Sorry to be pedantic. Description should be "[CALCITE-3302] Implement CLASSIFIER function for MATCH_RECOGNIZE", not "CALCITE-3302 Implemented CLASSIFIER function for MATCH_RECOGNIZE."
Agree, sorry for missing that, I changed the title accordingly.
Yes, I logged https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-3307 for the AppVeyor issue.
will do
I'm closing this PR now as I already started to refactor it and reimplement it together with other functions like LAST. Nonetheless, thanks for your comments!
Who can help to review this patch?
cc @LiShuMing
Thanks for fixing this @rubenada !
@zabetak Any chance you can take a look and (if you're ok with it) merge this refactoring?
LGTM~ But I cannot see If `regexp_replace` supports `Char` type in `Mysql`?
Can you change the title to describe the end-user functionality?
Can you rebase on latest master?
Can you add the test case in the issue?
Sorry, just noticed the test case. :)
Please change the commit title by adding JIRA issue.
Thanks for the reminder @hsyuan !

> Can you change the title to describe the end-user functionality?

I change the title of the PR and the commit messag to "Describe the end-user functionality of REGEXP_REPLACE". Please correct me if I mistook your meaning.

> LGTM~ But I cannot see If `regexp_replace` supports `Char` type in `Mysql`?

In the document on [calcite site](https://calcite.apache.org/docs/reference.html). `CHAR(n)` stands for `Fixed-width character string`. And I add a test case for `CHAR(n)`, it works well. So, I think it's OK to add `CHAR` type in the allowed signature string.
Closing since the PR is superseded by https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/1432
@hsyuan  Done.
Dont use assert false. You should throw AssertionError. Then you can remove the useless return null.
We dont use [MINOR].
@danny0405 What is replacement for EnumerableSemiJoin.java ?
EnumerableNestedLoopJoin
Sorry I will edit it .
@danny0405 Thank you.

As @danny0405 said, EnumerableNestedLoopJoin can support SemiJoin with any type of join condition.
In case of SemiJoin with equi-join condition, EnumerableHashJoin can be used as a replacement too.
@amitvc Please take a look, this change will help you in the upgrade to 1.21
@zabetak Maybe we should put the change and equivalent plan to the 1.21 release nodes or breaking changes, this would help the user for the upgrade.

Hi @zabetak, I understand your concerns connected with this change, but I think that it is too unlikely that this change breaks existing clients, since currently if the rule does not have a provided description, it includes `in` and `out` conventions into the description, so it will be broken only for the case when clients used only rules with provided description and convention with illegal name. But even in this case, I think, clients may update the convention name to match the desired pattern.

Sorry for replying too late., I have been busy with other things in the past few months so that I have not noticed these comments. @ihuzenko Thanks for you PR, It's good.But I notice that it still not solve the problem that the result of JdbcConvention#toString() maybe not obey the description pattern of the RelOptRule. Since the convention name can beassigned when JdbcSchema is created and the name maybe notvalid in a rule description. So if we can not find a way tonormalize the convention name, can we throw a prompt to the client?

I'm going to merge this PR the way it is right now. Le'ts treat the remaining problems in a new issue if necessary. Thanks @ihuzenko  and @wenhuitang  for working on this and sorry for being the one who was stalling this issue.
@zabetak hello, it seems CALCITE-3115 should change JdbcToEnumerableConverterRule's descriptionPrefix  too.(It was forgotten)
The `out` convention is added in the `ConverterRule` class.

@hsyuan @vlsi 
How do you think about this one?
Would you please take a look when you have time?
Thanks a lot ~

> The `out` convention is added in the `ConverterRule` class.

Yes, So the `out` in the JdbcToEnumerableConverterRule seems useless.
Well, i got your idea, thanks.
Thanks for noticing. The 1.21.0 release is on its way so we will handle it afterwards unless we discover other serious issues.

>  if ENUMERABLE_MERGE_JOIN_RULE enabled by default, lots of plan checking for EnumerableHashJoin need to be modified

What do you mean by that? Can you give an example?

Update:
Never mind, I got what you mean.
You can include this change in another PR, so I will close this one.
forgot to tag @julianhyde
@julianhyde Done
Merged in https://github.com/apache/calcite/commit/955d4ea7b30b85519529c1c77662fa04141bfa89.
Sorry, my fault. I am wondering will changing `correlation` to `correlationId` cause compatibility issue? Your previous commit might make more sense in this regard. What do you think?

As ever, I think it is more useful if your commit message describes the problem you are trying to fix, not what you did to fix it.

The perfect commit message would be as follows:
```
[CALCITE-3322] There are two same testcase in RelMetadataTest ()

Alter testcase RelMetadataTest.testRowCountSortLimit0, adding LIMIT 0 so
that it is not the same as testRowCountSortLimit.

Close apache/calcite#1439
```
@hsyuan  @julianhyde  thanks for your comments.

> Sorry, my fault. I am wondering will changing `correlation` to `correlationId` cause compatibility issue? Your previous commit might make more sense in this regard. What do you think?

Yes, compatibility issue might be a problem. I reset it to the previous commit.
Thanks for review. @hsyuan

There are many duplicate code in `RelWriterTest`.
And I refine the code in this PR too.
@shenh062326 What Julian means is the git commit message, not only for the PR.

I put the logic of adding check for INTERVAL_TYPES together with adding check for the empty case of partition key or order key when deserialize RexOver. Because they are both related to function of deserializing from json string.
I have checked all the sub-class of ConverterRule. Only JdbcToEnumerableConverterRule contains useless out in its descriptionPrefix .
@hsyuan  @julianhyde  Alter commit message, Done.
Thanks for the confirm @wenhuitang , i'm not asking more and +1 for this patch.
@vvysotskyi can you please take a look at this? The PR is opened based on our discussions in Jira.
@xndai, I'll try to review it by the end of this week.
Can you add the JIRA case number?

There's some refactoring to be done. There is already a `SqlDialect.getCastSpec` method. That method needs to be documented (and if necessary refactored). 

It's crazy that your fix works by overriding `SqlDialect.unparseCall` when there is already a `SqlDialect.getCastSpec`, and there a lot of other code in `SqlImplementor.toSql(RexProgram program, RexNode rex)`.

As part of your fix, can you sort out this mess, and make it a bit better rather than a bit worse?
Sorry, JIRA case number has been added,  and actually,  I ignore SqlDialect.getCastSpec method and I will try fix it better.

@julianhyde @ffmax I want to clarify that it is me that suggests to modify the `SqlDialect#unparseCall` method, previously i didn't pay attention to the `SqlDialect.getCastSpec` method which i think is the right place that need modification. I think we should add some detailed documentation for method `SqlDialect.getCastSpec`.

Sorry for that @ffmax !
Another question: it seems that Hive 2.x already supports `Integer`, but we can not distinguish the Hive version here.

> +1, but recommend changing the title to `AssertionError when reducing decimals` so that the title can describe what is the problem this PR is trying to fix.

OK. I update the title of this PR and the commit log.

I have a UT failure at MongoAdapterTest.testGroupByAvgSumCount() due to the operator sequence change. My understand is this does not actually affect the plan. But would appreciate if someone is more familiar with the background can review it. Thx.
Also I notice under debugger that RelNode tree can have more than one RelOptCluster. I haven't dig into that. But if this is the case, your #2 bullet point in your change description may not be true.
Hello, @julianhyde @michaelmior @hsyuan Do you have time to look at this PR again? Thanks a lot.
Hi @xndai if you have two clusters in the same `RelNode` tree then it sounds like a bug. There are various checks in the VolcanoPlanner to avoid this situation.
I find It might be necessary to add  INT enum in  SqlTypeName, if we want to refactor getCastSpec to do with the issue.
@danny0405 Yeah, Hive 2.x already supports Integer, but using the common type between Hive1.x and Hive2.x may be better?

Hey @DonnyZone , apologies for my late reply but I've been rather busy lately. Whenever you get the chance please rebase your code with the current master and resolve the conflicts. Also feel free to remove dead-code (less code -> faster review) :)
Pls squash commits into one and add your name to commit message as `(FirstName LastName)`

@zabetak @vvysotskyi I look closer and find two tests cases in JdbcTest where I see rel nodes have different RelOptCluster instances - testLateralJoin and testExpandViewWithLateralJoin. It looks like during parsing when there's view table and ViewTable.expandView() would create a new SqlToRelConverter instance which then would use a different RelOptCluster instance for rel nodes it creates.

Is this expected?
@zabetak Sure, thanks! I will rebase it in the next few days.

In current code of `SqlOperatorBinding#isOperandNull`, the doc for param of allowCast is like below
```
* @param allowCast whether to regard CAST(constant) as a constant
```
Shall we update it and update 'constant' with 'null' in this PR ? That will be more clear.
I'm not sure if this PR could include such change.

Thanks for your fix @DonnyZone and it's good for me overall ~
I left minor comments and you can check if they are valid.
According to the current semantics in `SqlUtil#isNullLiteral`, we can replace the word "constant" with "null" here.

Pls squash your commit into one. Message should say
> [CALCITE-1234] Description (FirstName LastName)

> Pls squash commits into one and add your name to commit message as `(FirstName LastName)`

Squashed all commits and added message in the required format.

> I didn't have time to follow the logic on first review, but it looks good. I only have quibbles about naming and formatting. How about 'SqlMatchFunction' instead of 'SqlMrFunction'? (We tend to abbreviate "match-recognize" to "match", so there's no need for the "mr" acronym.)
> 
> Also we tend to put parentheses on the end of the line, so
> 
> ```
>   foo(
>      bar)));
> ```
> 
> rather than
> 
> ```
>   foo(
>     bar)
>   ));
> ```

Agree with both of your points, I updated the branch respectively. I hope I found (nearly) all places with the bracket-thingy.
Thanks @julianhyde!

Pls read [contributing doc](https://calcite.apache.org/develop/#contributing). JIRA id should be in square brackets : `[CALCITE-3335]`

Your commit message has some redundant messages (probably due to squash).

Pls mention (in commit message) that it is related to ElasticSearch adapter:

> [CALCITE-3335] ElasticSearch adapter. Introduce configuration parameter "hosts" which deprecates previous "coordinates". (FirstName LastName)
Done
Not sure, is it necessary to squash the commits when merge ?
